sect1.title: Technical Skills

sect2.title: Case Formulation
sect2.para: Case formulation Case formulation (also known as case conceptualization) involves comprehensively understanding a client’s presenting concern, any precipitating and maintaining factors, and a hypothesis of the underlying factors driving the problem, along with their origins. Although a full, thorough overview of case formulation is beyond the scope of this chapter, it is an important technical foundation for clinical and diagnostic interviewing. Indeed, some research suggests that incorporating case formulation into your interview framework results in better outcomes for clients (Persons et al., 2006 ). A good case formulation stems from a collaborative clinical interview with the client to collect pertinent data related not only to diagnosis but also to various influencing factors that may be driving a diagnosis. Predictions about the client’s diagnoses diagnoses are then made based on the case formulation, and the hypotheses are then tested by applying a treatment plan that aligns with the client’s and therapist’s goals for treatment (Persons, 2022 ).

To build on this collaborative process process , a useful case formulation is rooted in an effective diagnostic interview. As reviewed later in this section, clinical interviews can be unstructured, semi-structured, or structured. With any interview type, a good starting point is to gain an understanding of the current problem(s). A longstanding psychotherapy theory is that clients present for treatment when feeling demoralized (Frank, 1974 ), so it is also important to assess why the client presented for treatment at this time and whether any functional impairment is present. As discussed earlier in this chapter, it is important to gather this pertinent information while also maintaining rapport and collaborative interpersonal dynamics. To advance case formulation, additional information should also be gathered about the client’s presentation.

sect1.sect2:
Behavioral Observations
The content a client communicates is just one source of information. Another important source of information comes from observable features features , which can provide additional insight into client strengths and problem(s). For instance, the client may present with what they are calling “depression,” but you notice their affect is within normal limits even though they described their mood as “sad.” A client may be presenting for treatment for court-ordered alcohol misuse treatment and appear to have an unsteady gait and slurred speech despite them insisting that they are sober. Behavioral observations can help develop understanding of the client’s problems and place some of their problems into context.
In many instances, clinicians include behavioral observations in their reports and integrate them into their diagnostic rationales and case formulation. The first step in behavioral observation is to identify and operationalize behaviors behaviors consistent with the presenting problem. For instance, we may expect a client presenting with problems related to social anxiety disorder to appear anxious speaking with us (e. g., avoiding eye contact, turning red when disclosing sensitive information). sect2.title: Diagnostic Classification and Interviewing Frameworks
sect2.para: It is important to note that alternative models for assessing mental health disorders have been put forth and include the Research Domain Criteria (RDoC; Insel et al., 2010 ), the Hierarchical Taxonomy Model of Psychopathology (HiTOP) Hierarchical Taxonomy Model of Psychopathology (HiTOP) (Kotov et al., 2017 ), and the Alternative Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD) (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ; Krueger et al., 2012 ).

RDoC was an initiative put forth by the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) to move away from categorical-polythetic classification systems. RDoC is meant to (1) quantify dimensional domains as they relate to behaviors and neural systems and (2) foster research to validate these dimensions defined by neurobiology and behavioral measures that cut across current disorder categories. It is important to note that RDoC was not developed to replace current diagnostic systems; rather, it was created to be used as a framework to increase fidelity within research findings.

HiTOP HiTOP is a more recent initiative that builds upon decades of evidence regarding the structure of psychopathology. Regardless of the types of indicators used, HiTOP has consistently replicated (Forbes et al., 2024 ; Kotov et al., 2021 ; Ringwald et al., 2021 , 2023 ). A number of self-report measures are aligned with assessing dimensions within the HiTOP framework, including the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory-3 (MMPI-3; Ben-Porath & Tellegen, 2020a , b ) and the Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI; Morey, 1991 , 2020 ). The creation of additional self-report measures and a structured clinical interview for HiTOP is currently underway.

sect2.title: Ways of Interviewing
sect2.para: Diagnostic interviewing Diagnostic interviewing can be conceptualized as being either unstructured, semi-structured, or structured (Mueller & Segal, 2014 ). The type of diagnostic interview one chooses to use is dependent on time, complexity, and whether reliability in diagnosing is a high priority.
